title: DIVE into the Event-Based Browsing of Linked Historical Media

author: Victor de Boer, Netherlands Institute for Sound and Vision

segmentation: So my name is Victor, the bar.
I'm not only from Fu University Amsterdam, but also from the Netherlands Institute of Sound and Vision or built in clouds.
And that sets the stage for the lot of Dutch words that might probably come by today.

So this is this is presentation about our challenge submission on the dive tool in which we have at all, that lets you dive into historical media media about historical events from different culture heritage institutes.
So our tool is really meant for digital humanities researchers.
It's an open web tool so everybody can access it, but we really have started with the user experience and by looking at what our potential users want to do.
So we want to support with this tool.
Digital humanities researchers, specifically media researchers that use media.
I want to browse through media to get a better grip on what happened in in history.
And one of the things that we found out through previous research which is cited below is.
The notion that exploitive research is a key part of the information needs of these historical researchers.

These digital humanities researchers so not only just search where you know what you want to find with also exploration, where you can form new hypothesis about what happened, an what different media might say about these events.
So our tool, the dive tool is really an example of explorative search expertise search interface.

There's a whole pipeline and what we extract are persons, places, concepts, time, name, times, definitions, and events.
So this notion of events is very important in our in our way of thinking about how you want to present these media objects to digital humanities researchers.

On the images.

Existing hypothesis, for example.
